Lesson 2: Projecting Costs

Image by gpointstudio under Freepik modified from the original

Now that we’ve considered how money will come in, we’ll also want to plan for what you’ll spend in the coming year. This is important for creating the budget as well as managing costs throughout the year. Use the Expense Categories handout for reference as needed.

Instructions: Select each tab to learn about some of the most important considerations for projecting costs.

  • Review Historical Spending
  • Fixed and Variable Expenses
  • Future Goals
  • Shared Services

Review Historical Spending

Image by iconicbestiary under Freepik

As we covered in the budget process, it will be very helpful to look at what has happened in the past. You’ll be able to see what costs have remained constant and what may vary from year to year. Looking back at one year is good, but it’s even better to look back at expenses over multiple years. This will help you understand if there is consistency from year to year or if you have major fluctuations. If the latter is true, you will need to understand what causes the fluctuations in order to project future expenses.

Fixed and Variable Expenses

Image by freepik under Freepik

Expenses need to be organized into two categories: fixed and variable.

Fixed expenses are basic operating costs that must be paid and tend to remain consistent from period‐to‐period, like rent or mortgage costs, liability insurance, etc. You know the total cost that you can assign to your program for the year and they won’t change unless something significant changes in your program. You can accurately anticipate these costs.

Variable expenses are the things that can go up or down based on changes in your program. For example, if your enrollment changes, your food, supplies, and materials costs may change, too. These costs are dependent on enrollment and other changes.

Understanding the difference between predictable fixed costs and variable costs that require more consideration (like enrollment) is very important when building a budget and projecting costs throughout the year. In order to budget for variable expenses you’ll need to consider what influences those costs and what may be different than in prior years, if the cost is recurring. If a cost is new, you won’t have the benefit of historical information and you’ll need to closely monitor actual expenses against your assumptions throughout the year.

Future Goals

Image by freepik under Freepik modified from the original

What are your goals for the coming year? No matter how small or big–it’s vital to think through the costs associated with achieving your goal and where you’ll source the income to pay for it. This prevents surprises at the end of the year, like realizing that spending exceeded program income. Building a budget and reviewing it throughout the year will help prevent unexpected detrimental outcomes.

Shared Services

Image by rawpixel.com under Freepik

Shared services are a way for providers to work together to share costs and deliver services in a more streamlined and efficient way. Similar programs can share administrative functions, like financial and marketing services, as well as benefit from purchasing pools with vendor discounts for things that they already purchase, like food, supplies, and payroll services.

The money saved on shared services can be redirected back into your program to work on goals like participating in or increasing your quality rating and improvement system (QRIS) level and improving program quality for children.

The ultimate goal of shared services is to reduce the administrative burden on providers and free up time and money to be redirected into providing high quality care for children. Michigan doesn’t currently have a formal shared services platform; however, there are some excellent resources on the Great Start to Quality website that include a job board, quality resources and a place to checkout available savings for providers: Great Start To Quality Resources .
